guide.title: Gentoo Linux Install Reference
guide.author: Steven Wagner
guide.abstract: The Quick install reference covers all details of the install process in a non-verbose manner. Users should already have prior experience with installing gentoo linux if they want to follow this guide.

body.p: The installation ISOs are on the Gentoo Mirrors. Detailed descriptions of the different CDs are available in the Gentoo Store. CD 1 contains everything you need to install Gentoo Linux quickly and without a connection to the Internet. CD2 is optional and contains pre-compiled packages such as KDE, GNOME, OpenOffice, Mozilla, Evolution and more.
Boot from the first Gentoo CD. Press <F1> and/or <F2> to see what boot options are available. Press <ENTER> at the bootscreen to continue with the default kernel. You'll eventually receive a prompt.
body.pre: # date (Make sure your time and date is correct. If wrong, set it with date MMDDhhmmCCYY ) # modprobe module_name (Optional - Load any necessary modules) # net-setup eth0 (Configure the network) # fdisk /dev/hda (Partition your drive)
body.p: The recommended setup is a 64 meg boot volume with ext3, a swap partition twice the size of your available RAM, and the rest for your root partition using ReiserFS.
Initialise your partitions using mke2fs (Ext2), mke2fs -j (Ext3), mkreiserfs (ReiserFS), mkfs.xfs (XFS), mkfs.jfs (JFS) and mkswap (swap partition). For instance: mke2fs -j /dev/hda3.
Continue by mounting the partitions and extracting the appropriate stage file.
body.pre: (Activate the swap partition) # swapon /dev/hdax (Mount the root partition) # mount /dev/hdax /mnt/gentoo (Create the boot mountpoint) # mkdir /mnt/gentoo/boot (Mount the boot partition) # mount /dev/hdax /mnt/gentoo/boot (Go to the mountpoint) # cd /mnt/gentoo (Extract a stage tarball...) # tar -xvjpf /mnt/cdrom/stages/stage?-*.tar.bz2 (or download the latest tarball...) # links http://gentoo.oregonstate.edu/releases/x86/1.4/ ( ... and extract) # tar -xvjpf stage* (GRP-only: unpack a portage tree) # tar -xvjf /mnt/cdrom/snapshots/portage-*.tar.bz2 -C /mnt/gentoo/usr (GRP-only: copy over distfiles) # cp -R /mnt/cdrom/distfiles /mnt/gentoo/usr/portage/distfiles (GRP-only: copy over packages) # cp -a /mnt/cdrom/packages /mnt/gentoo/usr/portage/packages (Select a mirror) # mirrorselect -i -o >> /mnt/gentoo/etc/make.conf (Copy over nameserver information) # cp /etc/resolv.conf /mnt/gentoo/etc/resolv.conf (Mount the proc filesystem) # mount -t proc proc /mnt/gentoo/proc (Chroot into the new environment) # chroot /mnt/gentoo /bin/bash (Load the necessary variables) # env-update; source /etc/profile (Network-only, non-GRP: update Portage) # emerge sync

(Change USE, CFLAGS and CXXFLAGS. Stage1 can also change CHOST) # nano -w /etc/make.conf (Stage1 only: bootstrap system) # cd /usr/portage; scripts/bootstrap.sh (Stage1, Stage2 only: install base system) # emerge system
body.p: Next we set up the necessary information:
body.pre: (Set timezone information) # ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/path/to/timezonefile /etc/localtime (Edit fstab file) # nano -w /etc/fstab
body.p: Use the following as a template (don't copy verbatim) for /etc/fstab:
body.pre: # <fs> <mountpoint> <type> <opts> <dump/pass> /dev/hdax /boot ext3 noauto,noatime 1 2 /dev/hdax / reiserfs noatime 0 1 /dev/hdax none swap sw 0 0 /dev/cdroms/cdrom0 /mnt/cdrom iso9660 noauto,ro,user 0 0 none /proc proc defaults 0 0 none /dev/shm tmpfs defaults 0 0 /dev/hdax /mnt/dosc ntfs ro,noatime,umask=0222 0 0
body.p: Continue by installing the Linux kernel:
body.pre: (Install the kernel sources) # emerge -k sys-kernel/gentoo-sources (Configure your kernel using genkernel...) # emerge -k genkernel; genkernel (or (1) manually build your kernel) # cd /usr/src/linux; make menuconfig; ( (2) Include VM fs, /proc fs, /dev fs, /dev fs auto mount at boot) ( (3) Compile your kernel) # make dep && make clean bzImage modules modules_install ( (4) Copy over the kernel) # cp arch/i386/boot/bzImage /boot; cp System.map /boot
body.p: Now install other tools you might want:
body.pre: (Install system logger; choice: sysklogd, metalog, msyslog, syslog-ng) # emerge -k app-admin/syslog-ng (Have the systemlogger automatically started at boot) # rc-update add syslog-ng default (Install cron daemon; choice: vcron, dcron, fcron) # emerge -k sys-apps/vcron (Have the cron daemon automatically started at boot) # rc-update add vcron default (genkernel users only: install hotplug) # emerge -k hotplug (genkernel users only: have hotplug automatically started at boot) # rc-update add hotplug default (Non-ext2,ext3 users only; choice: reiserfsprogs, xfsprogs, jfsutils) # emerge -k reiserfsprogs
body.p: If you need specialised kernel ebuilds, now is a good time to install them:
body.pre: # emerge -k pcmcia-cs (or emu10k1, nforce-net, nforce-audio, e100, e1000, ati-drivers, rp-pppoe) # VIDEO_CARDS="yourcard" emerge xfree-drm (for ATI Radeon up to 9200, Rage128, Matrox, Voodoo and other cards)
body.p: Finalise the settings for your Gentoo system:
body.pre: (Set root password) # passwd (Create a user) # useradd your_user -m -G users,wheel,audio -s /bin/bash (Set password for that user) # passwd your_user (Set the system hostname) # echo mymachine > /etc/hostname (Set the system domainname) # echo mydomain.com > /etc/dnsdomainname (Set the hostsfile, at least set "127.0.0.1 mymachine") # nano -w /etc/hosts

(Setup networking; dhcp-users should set iface_eth0="dhcp") # nano -w /etc/conf.d/net (List modules to be loaded at startup) # nano -w /etc/modules.autoload.d/kernel-2.4 (Configure basic system settings; follow comments) # nano -w /etc/rc.conf (Non-PCMCIA only: start networking automatically at boot) # rc-update add net.eth0 default (Only if you have multiple network interfaces:) (1) Create initscripts for each interface) # ln -s /etc/init.d/net.eth0 /etc/init.d/net.ethx (2) Automatically start at boot if no PCMCIA) # rc-update add net.ethx default (PCMCIA only: verify /etc/conf.d/pcmcia and load PCMCIA at boot) # rc-update add pcmcia boot
body.p: Now install a bootloader. Left is for grub, right for lilo:
body.pre: # emerge -k grub | # emerge -k lilo # grub | # nano -w /etc/lilo.conf grub> root (hd0,0) (Boot partition) | boot=/dev/hda grub> setup (hd0) (Install on MBR) | prompt grub> quit | timeout=50 # nano -w /boot/grub/grub.conf | default=gentoo default 0 | timeout 15 | # Genkernel only: splashimage=(hd0,0)/grub/splash.xpm.gz | image=/boot/kernel-<kernel version> | root=/dev/hda3 title=Gentoo Linux | label=gentoo root (hd0,0) | # Genkernel only: | # Non-genkernel only: kernel (hd0,0)/kernel-<kernel version> root=/dev/hda3 | image=/boot/bzImage initrd (hd0,0)/initrd-<kernel version> | root=/dev/hda3 # Non-genkernel only: | label=gentoo kernel (hd0,0)/bzImage | | # For dualbooting: # For dualbooting: | other=/dev/hdaX title=Windows XP | label=windows root (hd0,5) | chainloader (hd0,5)+1 | # /sbin/lilo
body.p: Now unmount all partitions and reboot into your new system:
body.pre: (Updating configuration files) # etc-update (Exiting the chroot) # exit; cd / (Unmounting partitions) # umount /mnt/gentoo/boot /mnt/gentoo/proc /mnt/gentoo (Reboot; Remove the install CD from the tray) # reboot (After booting:) (ADSL-users only) # adsl-setup (GRP-users only, optional CD2 usage) ( (1) Mount CD2) # mount /dev/cdrom /mnt/cdrom ( (2) Copy over packages) # cp -a /mnt/cdrom/packages/* /usr/portage/packages/ ( (3) Install extra software) # emerge -k xfree gnome kde mozilla openoffice-bin ( (4) Configure your Xserver) # /usr/X11R6/bin/xf86config
body.p: You can get more information from the Gentoo Documentation.
